THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 23, 1920

2

CONCERT GREAT SUCCESS
Glee Club and Instrumental Club Give
Excellent Performance at Towson-Boyd'. Egyptian Dancing Attraction of the Evening.

3frrbrrirk

•r"•

The concert given by the Hopkins Combined Musical Clubs at
the State Normal School, at, Towson, last Priday evening, was
probably the best of the club's performance (111 ri Hg the present season. Both the vocal and instrumental numbers were rendered in
a highly creditable way, and were
truly deserving of the enthusiastic applause of the audience. The
Egyptian dancing specialty, by
Holmes Boyd, was also worthy of
praise; indeed, it received more
apulause than any other number
of the program.
"Mike" Bowers' absence from
the city prevented his taking his
accustomed seat at the piano, but
in Baughman was found a substitute of almost equal ivory tickling
ability. Riggs and Hambleton
made a special appeal with their
thoroughly Trawaiian number.
"Dardanella," as played by the
Jazz Orchestra, was one of the
concert's most conspicuous features. Harmony and "pep" were
present in unusually generous
quantities, and, to judge by the
appreciative reception accorded
the orchestral numbers, the audience had an unlimited appetite for
jazz music of that inspiring
quality.
The Glee Club, clearly showing
the results of continued practice,
gave an almost flawless performance, and brought into distinct
favor the various numbers of a
tastefully selected program. Several well-received vocal selections
were also given by the University
Quartette, which made a great hit
in its special song about Towson.
A dance given by the students of
the Normal School succeeded the
cbncert. Music was furnished by
the Jazz Orchestra. The concert
program follows:

Contributions May Be Given to Members
of the Committee or Deposited at
the Treasurer's Office— No Contributions Will Be Solicited.

This is the week in which America is contributing to the "America's Gift to France" Fund. As
was stated in this paper a few
weeks ago, the purpose of this
fund is to present to the French
Republic, in return for the Statue
of Liberty, given to. this country
by France in 1885, the blacMonnies Statue commemorating the
Battle of the Marne. THE NEWSLETTER. has been placed in charge
of the campaign at Hopkins, and
a committee representing it, composed of E. G. Huey, Richard Dallam and William M. Passau°, will
receive the contributions of Hopkins men. These men will be at
the postoffice and the Barn at
lunch time every day this week,
and will keep account of the number of subscribers. Contributions
will also be received at the Treasurer's office at any time during
office hours.
• The number of subscribers to
the fund is of vastly more importance than the amount received.'
The Statue of Liberty was unmistakably a gift of the entire French
people and, in the same way, the
memorial on the Marne must come
from all classes in America, as the
spontaneous gift of the whole
American people.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAR. 23, 1920

This week the campaign for contributions to the MacMonnies
Statue Fund is being made at
I I opkins. This donation should
not be looked upon in the same
light as are other requests for
money; this fund will be raised by
all classes, rich and poor alike,
to show France the true love and
respect which the United States,
as a whole, feel towards her comrade in arms during the late war.
and it should be considered a
privilege to all red-blooded Americans to be allowed to contribute.
The amount of money given by
the individual is not so important
as the sentiment attached to the
gift. The amount required to be
raised is only $250,000, a sum
which should be fully subscribed
in short order, but Hopkins wants
to have her name on the subscriber's book in big letters, and
the only way for this to be accomplished is for each and every one
of us to give his mite.
Let's try to make this a 100 per
cent. contribution.
In the face of the hardest and
best track schedule which it has
ever been the opportunity of the
Johns Hopkins University to assume, the track management is
facing the dilemma of not having
enough men to make complete entries in every race!
To what can this lethargy ori
the part of the Johns Hopkins students be attributed? To the loss
of the cage? That has certainly
placed a large obstacle in the path
of the indoor squad, which may
be considered in great measure accountable for the showing made

at the Fifth Regiment Armory
meet; but now the team is practicing at Homewood, and has been
doing so for the past several
weeks. The loss of the cage cannot then be the cause. To the variable and largely disagreeable
weather conditions which have
prevailed this year? It would
seem so. Yet, this is a terrible
accusation to be forced to admit.
It seems that the general run
of students in our greatly increased student body are perfectly
satisfied, when the day's work at
the University is over, to let the
hard, grimy work of the athletic
field fall heavily on the shoulders
of "Brother George," who will
loyally be there.
Speaking from the viewpoint of
"big" athletics at Hopkins, one
in u s t confess discouragement,
when the size of our track squad
is measured against the demands
of the best schedule ever presented to Hopkins students. We cannot be unmindful of the fact that
track work is hard work, and is no
place for a man who feels that
every member of a team can work
but himself. But the rewards amrtly justify the denial, as is evidenced by the men of the past who
stuck, plodded—and succeeded.
It is doubtful if the students of
the University appreciate the demands and the excellencies of the
track schedule for 1920. One does
not see such a series of contests
undertaken or presented to its
students by any of the larger universities.
For instance, on May 1, the
Penn Relays, at Philadelphia; on
May 8, the South Atlantic Intercollegiates at Blacksburg, Va.;
on May 15, the Middle States
Inter - collegiates, at Rutgers,
Brunswick, N. J.; and the I.
c. A. A. A. meet, on May 28
and 29, in Philadelphia, form a
permanent skeleton of a schedule which would be the envy
of allY other university in the
country. Hopkins is brought into
competition with the best in the
North, South, -Middle Atlantic
States, the West and Pacific
Coast. One wonders whether the
average undergraduate student appreciates the honor which goes
with the above.
In addition to the above meets,
dual meets are scheduled with
Swarthmore and Delaware Colleges. All of these, together with
an inter-class meet on April 17,
presents a continuous track schedule from the middle of April to
the last of May, comprising seven
first-class outdoor engagements,
and bringing Hopkins in touch
and actual competition with the
largest universities of the country.
The track authorities have
brought about a wonderful opportunity for the University, and it
is only fair that it should have
the whole-hearted • support and
backing of those who call the University their own. This means unselfish effort, self-sacrifice and
hard work. It &es not compre-

hend letting other men carry the
banner, or manifest itself in running home immediately after the
school session is over. It means
keeping off the blacklist, and a
denial of personal pleasures, such
as tea parties, dances, cigarettes,,
late hours and kindred enjoyments, which can very soon produce a dangerous effeteness. It
means all of this, but the track
management believes that there is
a fundamental spirit at Hopkins,
and that all it needs is an awakening. On the faith of that belief,
the above schedule was undertaken.
The track team needs support;
it needs a larger squad. The students can help. Is it worth while
to compete with Harvard, Ya-le,
Princeton, California, Lafayette,
Swarthmore, Rutgers and others?
If it is, show some college spirit
and come out.
Commander McFarland Lectures.
Commander Walter M. -McFarland, the manager of the marine

department of the Babcock and
Wilcox. Co., New York, delivered
one of the most interesting lectures in the Aldred series last
Weinesday, taking for his title,
"Common Sense in Engineering."
"Common sense," said Commander McFarland, "is applying without prejudice the knowledge that
you already • possess." He also
laid emphasis on the fact that to
use common sense a man should
not be uneducated and without
proper equipment as is the popular idea, but just the contrary.
Commander McFarland told in
a. very interesting way some personal experiences that he has had
with men who have combined their
technical training and common
sense with the best results. Chief
among these men. was Mr. Westinghouse, in whose employ Commander McFarland served for a
number of years. The story of
how- the Westinghouse Air Brake
for railroad cars came to be invented and perfected proves very
conclusively that a good measure
of common sense is well worth
having.
"Concealing Coloration and Cimoufla gip,"
Subject of Lecture.

On Thursday, March 25, an illustrated lecture on "Concealing
Coloration and Camouflage" will
be given by Mr. Gerald H. Thayer.
The lecture will take place at 4.30
P. M. in Room 120 of the Civil
Engineering Building.
Mr. Thayer, well known as an
artist, naturalist and author, is
carying out the work of his father,
an artist, in studying the protective coloring of animals. His
lecture will discuss the chief
points brought up in his book,
"Concealing Coloration in the Animal Kingdom." He maintains
that the colors which make birds
and animals conspicuous in some
situations in their customary
haunts render them practically invisible.

QUACKS FROM A QUACK

I

Hark ye, friends, students and
bull-slingers, lend me your ears,
for I am about to unfold to you
a fact of the utmost interest and
importance. They call "Doug"
Cotton "the mole!' Why? Don't
ask me. I don't know whether he
inherited the title or just accumulated it; but, be that as it may,
that which concerns us most right
at present is that the worthy Cotton passes under the name of
"Mole." Now, to get to my story;
"Mole" Cotton surprised his
friends and others a few nights
ago by dolling himself up in a
monkey suit.and going to a dance.
It was quite an elegant affair, not
the kind that most of you participate in down at the House of Horrors, the Automobile Club, but a
real society function, and all the
highbrows, they were there. The
story runs that the first person to
notice "Mole" Cotton's triumphant
entry into the glittering ballroom
was our own "Bob"
all, who
gently whispered to the fair maiden with whom he was toddling,
"See the Mole!" Now, as chance
w-ould have it, right in the line of
vision of above-mentioned fair
maiden was another maiden, also
fair, on the direct center of whose
neck was what all surgeons and
beauty specialists agree to call a
mole. Now, fair maiden No. 1,
interpreting "Bobby's" remark to
have been directed at fair maiden
No. 2, instead of at the illustrious
Cotton, blushed a delicate shade
of yellow- and tittered, "Oh, Bob,
you shouldn't notice such things."
Now, that's not so crying funny
in itself, but the point I want to
emphasize is that we should take
the young lady's advice and not
notice the "Mole" (I mean
"Mole" Cotton), he gets too confounded much notoriety anyway.
I don't know why I am putting
him in my Quack Column.
But suppose we forget the
"Mee" for the time being, and let
me tell you about this little fellow
Harrison, from V. M. I. The
other (lay a crowd of sophs spied
him walking with a freshman who
was committing the unpardonable
sin of putting his front feet in
his pockets. "Harrison, you ought
to be ashamed of yourself," they
called, "You, on the sophomore
pep committee, and walking with
a freshman who has his hands in
his pockets." "All right then,"
answered Harrison,. "Damn it, I
won2t walk with him." And he
fell in step with his irate classmates.
T was talking with "Doc"
French the other day, and he says
to me,"George, here's one for your
Quacks, one of my English Comp
students named Harden, came up
to my office and asked me, 'Dr.,
can you punish a man for something he hasn't done?"Why, no,
Mr. Harden,' I replied.

"Poldekin,". A Delightful Play, and
George Arliss, in Title Role, Always
in Command of Attraction

The Literary Club benefit at
Ford's last Thursday night, was a
big success, both from the standpoint of finances, and of the
amusement derived by the large
number of Hopkins men scattered
throughout the rather undersized
audience. The play, "Poldekin,"
by Booth Tarkington, proved to be
a very delightful arraignment of
the Bolshevist movement. While
not calculated to convince any
really abandoned Bolshevist that
his cause is wrong and futile, it
will provide many who were wavering with something tangible to
cling to; indeed, it will be hard
for anyone to reconcile himself to
accepting so drab an existence as
that which the particular group
of which Poldek in is a lowly member proposes. While not free from
many of the hokums which Mr.
Tarkington knows so well how to
use, the play is amazingly successful in accomplishing its announced "purpose," and in being
exceedingly amusing at the same
time.
The acting of Mr. Arliss, in the
title role, was buoyantly arresting. At all times, he was in complete control of the situation, and,
if he was just a trifle too gay; if
he showed just a bit too little of
his thinker's side, he may feel
justified in the knowledge that he
lifted the play out of the class of
"play with a purpose," and made
a warm, diverting human exhibit.
The Literary Club may congratulate itself on the felicity of
the substitution of such a play as
"Poldekin," for the girl and music
show originally announced.

Several weeks ago an announcement was made in the Baltiabore
Jewish, Times that the Intercollegiate Zionist Association was
making plans for a summer course
in agriculture at the National
Farm School, Doylestown, Pa. As
a result of this announcement,
Mr. Paul S. Levy, . of Reisterstown Md. has. generously offered
Hopkins Zionist Society
the .Johns'
a sum of money, to be known as
the Sarah Baron Levy Prize,
which will be. sufficient to send
one Hopkins man to the school for
a two-weeks' unit of the course.
As a result of a continuous demand on the -part of many students, a new section of the Zionist
study circle has been formed. This
section is primarily for those who
cannot attend the circle on Friday at 10.30 A. M. Section 2 will

announcement of the room will be

Senior Class Meeting.

The Senior Class met Monday.
March 15, President Townsend
presiding, to discuss plans for the
banquet, for Senior Weew and several other important nmtters.
George Wagner, whose three
years' experience as chairman of
the Banquet Committee, especially
qualifies him to take charge of arranging tile best banquet a Senior
Class rms ever had, is on the job,
and in his report to the class
stated that the "big feed" would
he held at the Emerson this year.
Aside from the banquet, there will
be a jazz band and dancers to add
to the hilarity of the occasion.
Mersereau, reporting for the
Senior Week Committee, suggested a tentative program, thereby
opening a general discussion of
the subject. Nothing definite was
adopted, however, in regard to the
actual program ; although it was
decided that the committee should
arrange several programs and submit them to the class, to be voted
on at a later meeting.
President Townsend and Fred
Bresee urged the members who
had not yet ,paid for their canes
to'do so at once.
The meeting was adjourned at
1 P. M.

2

CONCERT GREAT SUCCESS
Glee Club and Instrumental Club Give
Excellent Performance at Towson-Boyd'. Egyptian Dancing Attraction of the Evening.

3frrbrrirk

•r"•

The concert given by the Hopkins Combined Musical Clubs at
the State Normal School, at, Towson, last Priday evening, was
probably the best of the club's performance (111 ri Hg the present season. Both the vocal and instrumental numbers were rendered in
a highly creditable way, and were
truly deserving of the enthusiastic applause of the audience. The
Egyptian dancing specialty, by
Holmes Boyd, was also worthy of
praise; indeed, it received more
apulause than any other number
of the program.
"Mike" Bowers' absence from
the city prevented his taking his
accustomed seat at the piano, but
in Baughman was found a substitute of almost equal ivory tickling
ability. Riggs and Hambleton
made a special appeal with their
thoroughly Trawaiian number.
"Dardanella," as played by the
Jazz Orchestra, was one of the
concert's most conspicuous features. Harmony and "pep" were
present in unusually generous
quantities, and, to judge by the
appreciative reception accorded
the orchestral numbers, the audience had an unlimited appetite for
jazz music of that inspiring
quality.
The Glee Club, clearly showing
the results of continued practice,
gave an almost flawless performance, and brought into distinct
favor the various numbers of a
tastefully selected program. Several well-received vocal selections
were also given by the University
Quartette, which made a great hit
in its special song about Towson.
A dance given by the students of
the Normal School succeeded the
cbncert. Music was furnished by
the Jazz Orchestra. The concert
program follows:

Contributions May Be Given to Members
of the Committee or Deposited at
the Treasurer's Office— No Contributions Will Be Solicited.

This is the week in which America is contributing to the "America's Gift to France" Fund. As
was stated in this paper a few
weeks ago, the purpose of this
fund is to present to the French
Republic, in return for the Statue
of Liberty, given to. this country
by France in 1885, the blacMonnies Statue commemorating the
Battle of the Marne. THE NEWSLETTER. has been placed in charge
of the campaign at Hopkins, and
a committee representing it, composed of E. G. Huey, Richard Dallam and William M. Passau°, will
receive the contributions of Hopkins men. These men will be at
the postoffice and the Barn at
lunch time every day this week,
and will keep account of the number of subscribers. Contributions
will also be received at the Treasurer's office at any time during
office hours.
• The number of subscribers to
the fund is of vastly more importance than the amount received.'
The Statue of Liberty was unmistakably a gift of the entire French
people and, in the same way, the
memorial on the Marne must come
from all classes in America, as the
spontaneous gift of the whole
American people.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAR. 23, 1920

This week the campaign for contributions to the MacMonnies
Statue Fund is being made at
I I opkins. This donation should
not be looked upon in the same
light as are other requests for
money; this fund will be raised by
all classes, rich and poor alike,
to show France the true love and
respect which the United States,
as a whole, feel towards her comrade in arms during the late war.
and it should be considered a
privilege to all red-blooded Americans to be allowed to contribute.
The amount of money given by
the individual is not so important
as the sentiment attached to the
gift. The amount required to be
raised is only $250,000, a sum
which should be fully subscribed
in short order, but Hopkins wants
to have her name on the subscriber's book in big letters, and
the only way for this to be accomplished is for each and every one
of us to give his mite.
Let's try to make this a 100 per
cent. contribution.
In the face of the hardest and
best track schedule which it has
ever been the opportunity of the
Johns Hopkins University to assume, the track management is
facing the dilemma of not having
enough men to make complete entries in every race!
To what can this lethargy ori
the part of the Johns Hopkins students be attributed? To the loss
of the cage? That has certainly
placed a large obstacle in the path
of the indoor squad, which may
be considered in great measure accountable for the showing made

at the Fifth Regiment Armory
meet; but now the team is practicing at Homewood, and has been
doing so for the past several
weeks. The loss of the cage cannot then be the cause. To the variable and largely disagreeable
weather conditions which have
prevailed this year? It would
seem so. Yet, this is a terrible
accusation to be forced to admit.
It seems that the general run
of students in our greatly increased student body are perfectly
satisfied, when the day's work at
the University is over, to let the
hard, grimy work of the athletic
field fall heavily on the shoulders
of "Brother George," who will
loyally be there.
Speaking from the viewpoint of
"big" athletics at Hopkins, one
in u s t confess discouragement,
when the size of our track squad
is measured against the demands
of the best schedule ever presented to Hopkins students. We cannot be unmindful of the fact that
track work is hard work, and is no
place for a man who feels that
every member of a team can work
but himself. But the rewards amrtly justify the denial, as is evidenced by the men of the past who
stuck, plodded—and succeeded.
It is doubtful if the students of
the University appreciate the demands and the excellencies of the
track schedule for 1920. One does
not see such a series of contests
undertaken or presented to its
students by any of the larger universities.
For instance, on May 1, the
Penn Relays, at Philadelphia; on
May 8, the South Atlantic Intercollegiates at Blacksburg, Va.;
on May 15, the Middle States
Inter - collegiates, at Rutgers,
Brunswick, N. J.; and the I.
c. A. A. A. meet, on May 28
and 29, in Philadelphia, form a
permanent skeleton of a schedule which would be the envy
of allY other university in the
country. Hopkins is brought into
competition with the best in the
North, South, -Middle Atlantic
States, the West and Pacific
Coast. One wonders whether the
average undergraduate student appreciates the honor which goes
with the above.
In addition to the above meets,
dual meets are scheduled with
Swarthmore and Delaware Colleges. All of these, together with
an inter-class meet on April 17,
presents a continuous track schedule from the middle of April to
the last of May, comprising seven
first-class outdoor engagements,
and bringing Hopkins in touch
and actual competition with the
largest universities of the country.
The track authorities have
brought about a wonderful opportunity for the University, and it
is only fair that it should have
the whole-hearted • support and
backing of those who call the University their own. This means unselfish effort, self-sacrifice and
hard work. It &es not compre-

hend letting other men carry the
banner, or manifest itself in running home immediately after the
school session is over. It means
keeping off the blacklist, and a
denial of personal pleasures, such
as tea parties, dances, cigarettes,,
late hours and kindred enjoyments, which can very soon produce a dangerous effeteness. It
means all of this, but the track
management believes that there is
a fundamental spirit at Hopkins,
and that all it needs is an awakening. On the faith of that belief,
the above schedule was undertaken.
The track team needs support;
it needs a larger squad. The students can help. Is it worth while
to compete with Harvard, Ya-le,
Princeton, California, Lafayette,
Swarthmore, Rutgers and others?
If it is, show some college spirit
and come out.
Commander McFarland Lectures.
Commander Walter M. -McFarland, the manager of the marine

department of the Babcock and
Wilcox. Co., New York, delivered
one of the most interesting lectures in the Aldred series last
Weinesday, taking for his title,
"Common Sense in Engineering."
"Common sense," said Commander McFarland, "is applying without prejudice the knowledge that
you already • possess." He also
laid emphasis on the fact that to
use common sense a man should
not be uneducated and without
proper equipment as is the popular idea, but just the contrary.
Commander McFarland told in
a. very interesting way some personal experiences that he has had
with men who have combined their
technical training and common
sense with the best results. Chief
among these men. was Mr. Westinghouse, in whose employ Commander McFarland served for a
number of years. The story of
how- the Westinghouse Air Brake
for railroad cars came to be invented and perfected proves very
conclusively that a good measure
of common sense is well worth
having.
"Concealing Coloration and Cimoufla gip,"
Subject of Lecture.

On Thursday, March 25, an illustrated lecture on "Concealing
Coloration and Camouflage" will
be given by Mr. Gerald H. Thayer.
The lecture will take place at 4.30
P. M. in Room 120 of the Civil
Engineering Building.
Mr. Thayer, well known as an
artist, naturalist and author, is
carying out the work of his father,
an artist, in studying the protective coloring of animals. His
lecture will discuss the chief
points brought up in his book,
"Concealing Coloration in the Animal Kingdom." He maintains
that the colors which make birds
and animals conspicuous in some
situations in their customary
haunts render them practically invisible.

QUACKS FROM A QUACK

I

Hark ye, friends, students and
bull-slingers, lend me your ears,
for I am about to unfold to you
a fact of the utmost interest and
importance. They call "Doug"
Cotton "the mole!' Why? Don't
ask me. I don't know whether he
inherited the title or just accumulated it; but, be that as it may,
that which concerns us most right
at present is that the worthy Cotton passes under the name of
"Mole." Now, to get to my story;
"Mole" Cotton surprised his
friends and others a few nights
ago by dolling himself up in a
monkey suit.and going to a dance.
It was quite an elegant affair, not
the kind that most of you participate in down at the House of Horrors, the Automobile Club, but a
real society function, and all the
highbrows, they were there. The
story runs that the first person to
notice "Mole" Cotton's triumphant
entry into the glittering ballroom
was our own "Bob"
all, who
gently whispered to the fair maiden with whom he was toddling,
"See the Mole!" Now, as chance
w-ould have it, right in the line of
vision of above-mentioned fair
maiden was another maiden, also
fair, on the direct center of whose
neck was what all surgeons and
beauty specialists agree to call a
mole. Now, fair maiden No. 1,
interpreting "Bobby's" remark to
have been directed at fair maiden
No. 2, instead of at the illustrious
Cotton, blushed a delicate shade
of yellow- and tittered, "Oh, Bob,
you shouldn't notice such things."
Now, that's not so crying funny
in itself, but the point I want to
emphasize is that we should take
the young lady's advice and not
notice the "Mole" (I mean
"Mole" Cotton), he gets too confounded much notoriety anyway.
I don't know why I am putting
him in my Quack Column.
But suppose we forget the
"Mee" for the time being, and let
me tell you about this little fellow
Harrison, from V. M. I. The
other (lay a crowd of sophs spied
him walking with a freshman who
was committing the unpardonable
sin of putting his front feet in
his pockets. "Harrison, you ought
to be ashamed of yourself," they
called, "You, on the sophomore
pep committee, and walking with
a freshman who has his hands in
his pockets." "All right then,"
answered Harrison,. "Damn it, I
won2t walk with him." And he
fell in step with his irate classmates.
T was talking with "Doc"
French the other day, and he says
to me,"George, here's one for your
Quacks, one of my English Comp
students named Harden, came up
to my office and asked me, 'Dr.,
can you punish a man for something he hasn't done?"Why, no,
Mr. Harden,' I replied.

"Poldekin,". A Delightful Play, and
George Arliss, in Title Role, Always
in Command of Attraction

The Literary Club benefit at
Ford's last Thursday night, was a
big success, both from the standpoint of finances, and of the
amusement derived by the large
number of Hopkins men scattered
throughout the rather undersized
audience. The play, "Poldekin,"
by Booth Tarkington, proved to be
a very delightful arraignment of
the Bolshevist movement. While
not calculated to convince any
really abandoned Bolshevist that
his cause is wrong and futile, it
will provide many who were wavering with something tangible to
cling to; indeed, it will be hard
for anyone to reconcile himself to
accepting so drab an existence as
that which the particular group
of which Poldek in is a lowly member proposes. While not free from
many of the hokums which Mr.
Tarkington knows so well how to
use, the play is amazingly successful in accomplishing its announced "purpose," and in being
exceedingly amusing at the same
time.
The acting of Mr. Arliss, in the
title role, was buoyantly arresting. At all times, he was in complete control of the situation, and,
if he was just a trifle too gay; if
he showed just a bit too little of
his thinker's side, he may feel
justified in the knowledge that he
lifted the play out of the class of
"play with a purpose," and made
a warm, diverting human exhibit.
The Literary Club may congratulate itself on the felicity of
the substitution of such a play as
"Poldekin," for the girl and music
show originally announced.

Several weeks ago an announcement was made in the Baltiabore
Jewish, Times that the Intercollegiate Zionist Association was
making plans for a summer course
in agriculture at the National
Farm School, Doylestown, Pa. As
a result of this announcement,
Mr. Paul S. Levy, . of Reisterstown Md. has. generously offered
Hopkins Zionist Society
the .Johns'
a sum of money, to be known as
the Sarah Baron Levy Prize,
which will be. sufficient to send
one Hopkins man to the school for
a two-weeks' unit of the course.

section is primarily for those who
cannot attend the circle on Friday at 10.30 A. M. Section 2 will

announcement of the room will be

Senior Class Meeting.

The Senior Class met Monday.
March 15, President Townsend
presiding, to discuss plans for the
banquet, for Senior Weew and several other important nmtters.
George Wagner, whose three
years' experience as chairman of
the Banquet Committee, especially
qualifies him to take charge of arranging tile best banquet a Senior
Class rms ever had, is on the job,
and in his report to the class
stated that the "big feed" would
he held at the Emerson this year.
Aside from the banquet, there will
be a jazz band and dancers to add
to the hilarity of the occasion.
Mersereau, reporting for the
Senior Week Committee, suggested a tentative program, thereby
opening a general discussion of
the subject. Nothing definite was
adopted, however, in regard to the
actual program ; although it was
decided that the committee should
arrange several programs and submit them to the class, to be voted
on at a later meeting.
President Townsend and Fred
Bresee urged the members who
had not yet ,paid for their canes
to'do so at once.
The meeting was adjourned at
1 P. M.
